ygData.subject: Re: [archive-crawler] How can I create a complete graph in      Heritrix?
ygData.msgSnippet: Elverton, Have you looked at the metadata in the warcs? Each record should list extracted links regardless of whether they were crawled due to scoping rules.

Subject: Re: [archive-crawler] How can I create a complete graph in 
     Heritrix?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=494554680

Elverton,

Have you looked at the metadata in the warcs? Each record should list
extracted links regardless of whether they were crawled due to scoping rules.
Extract this set and intersect it with actual crawled uris to obtain a full
graph within what was crawled. You may also consider that the extractor also
has a [high] limit on the number of URIs it extracts.

Travis

On Mon, February 27, 2012 11:45 am, Elverton wrote:
> Hello everybody,
>
> As I sent a email to Gordon this afternoon (below), I want to record and get
> suggestion how can I get more information about a URI before it get 'uniqued'.
> As I read at "Mohr-et-al-2004', the way to decide what to do with a URI is at
> Prefetch, more exactly in Preselector. But I don't have a clue what filter or
> rule can help me. Any suggestions?
>
> Att.
> Elverton.
>
> => The original message:
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
>  Hello Gordon,
>
>  My name is Elverton. I'm doing a research in a metric to estimate the numbers
> of URL of a domain. I have a problem to solve and you think you can help me.
>
>  I want to make a complete graph of all URL's collected but all I have from
> crawl.log is the "father" of the URL and the URL. This would be necessary but
> I have an misundertanding about one thing: If heritrix collect one URL,
> suppose "yahoo.com" from "google.com". If the heritrix enter in "amazon.com"
> and found "yahoo.com" again, in crawl.log will appear:
>
>  - - - yahoo.com - google.com
>  - - - yahoo.com - amazon.com
>
>  or only:
>
>  - - - yahoo.com - google.com
>
>  So, the heritrix will ignore the found in "amazon.com" because it was already
> found in "google.com"?
>
>  Att.
>  Elverton.
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
>
> => Gordon's answer:
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
>
> You're correct, the crawl.log is not enough info to make a full web
> graph... it only records the exact paths that led to a URI being first
> discovered. You'd need to log more from the crawler before it 'uniques'
> the URIs for crawling purposes, or perform a post-crawl analysis on the
> full link-containing content, to create the web graph.
>
> - Gordon
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------
>
>
